title: 114_hr2712
content: The "Commonsense Reporting and Verification Act of 2015" includes provisions for a prospective reporting system, protection of dependent privacy, electronic statements, GAO studies, and an eligibility verification process for ACA subsidies. The Act may be cited as the "Commonsense Reporting and Verification Act of 2015". The "Commonsense Reporting and Verification Act of 2015" aims to minimize compliance burdens under the Affordable Care Act while protecting individual privacy. It includes provisions for a prospective reporting system and eligibility verification for ACA subsidies. The Act requires the implementation of a voluntary prospective reporting system by the Secretary of the Treasury within 180 days of enactment. Employers can use this system for plan years starting after December 31, 2015. The Secretary of the Treasury will implement a voluntary reporting system for employers to report essential coverage details for full-time employees, dependents, and certification information. The Secretary of the Treasury will implement a voluntary reporting system for employers to report essential coverage details for full-time employees, dependents, spouses, and part-time employees, ensuring coverage meets minimum value requirements and qualifies for certain criteria. The Secretary of the Treasury will implement a voluntary reporting system for employers to report essential coverage details for full-time employees, dependents, spouses, and part-time employees, ensuring coverage meets minimum value requirements, qualifies for affordability safe harbors, specifies coverage availability for full-time employees, and indicates any waiting periods. The Secretary of the Treasury will implement a voluntary reporting system for employers to report essential coverage details for employees, including waiting periods, to be reported before the open enrollment period. This system ensures secure access to information by Exchanges, the Data Services Hub, and the IRS to carry out their missions effectively. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will gather additional information on eligibility for premium tax credits and cost-sharing subsidies under the Affordable Care Act. A process will be established for agencies to follow up with employers and employees to obtain necessary information for eligibility determinations. The system created will gather information on eligibility for advance payment or cost-sharing subsidies and allow employers to provide updates on coverage changes for employees. Employers providing prospective reporting through the system created under subsection (a) will be considered as meeting return requirements of section 6056 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for the calendar year in which the plan year ends. Additionally, they will be deemed to satisfy the requirements of section 6056(c) of the Code if they furnish the necessary statement to the Internal Revenue Service. Employers can meet reporting requirements under section 6056 of the Internal Revenue Code by providing statements to the IRS and employees who have enrolled in a qualified health plan through the Exchange. Employers may use third parties to complete the filing for reporting requirements under section 6056 of the Internal Revenue Code. This does not affect the employer's liability under sections 6055 or 6056 of the Code. Each Exchange established under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act must notify employers when an employee or dependent enrolls in a qualified health plan through the Exchange. SEC. 4. PROTECTION OF DEPENDENT PRIVACY. Section 6055(b) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow for the use of an individual's name and date of birth in place of their TIN if not collected before January 1, 2014. The amendment allows for the use of an individual's name and date of birth instead of their TIN. Effective date applies to returns due after 60 days from enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. ELECTRONIC STATEMENTS. Section 6056(c) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow individuals to receive statements electronically if they have previously consented to it with their employer. The individual can receive statements in electronic form if they have previously consented to receive private health information electronically. The amendments made by this section allow individuals to receive private health information electronically if they have previously consented, effective for statements due after December 31, 2015. SEC. 6. GAO STUDIES. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study evaluating employer notification by Exchanges under the Affordable Care Act regarding full-time employees eligible for advance payment of premium tax credits from 2014 to 2016. The Comptroller General will study employer notification by Exchanges under the Affordable Care Act for full-time employees eligible for tax credits from 2014 to 2016, including data elements and notification process details. The study will analyze employer notification by Exchanges under the Affordable Care Act for full-time employees eligible for tax credits from 2014 to 2016, focusing on the process details, sufficiency of information provided, total number of notifications sent, and timeline of notifications. The study will examine employer notifications sent by Exchanges under the Affordable Care Act from 2014 to 2016, including the total number of notifications, differences in notification processes between Federal and State-Based Marketplaces, challenges faced, and recommendations for improvement. The Comptroller General will report on the challenges and recommendations regarding employer notifications under the Affordable Care Act, including the establishment of an appeals process for eligibility determinations. This report is due within one year of the Act's enactment. The Comptroller General will submit a report to relevant committees on the results of a study evaluating a prospective reporting system from January 1, 2017, to December. States will conduct a study evaluating the functionality of a reporting system from January 1, 2017, to December 31, 2017. The study will assess the accuracy of information collected, the number of employers using the system, and any implementation challenges. The Comptroller General will submit a report to relevant committees by July 1, 2018. The Comptroller General will submit a report to relevant committees on the results of the study evaluating a reporting system's functionality. SEC. 7. ELIGIBILITY VERIFICATION PROCESS FOR ACA SUBSIDIES. A marketplace can automatically reenroll an individual in a qualified health plan annually, as long as eligibility for subsidies is redetermined and changes in premiums and the Federal poverty level are considered. The marketplace must consider annual changes in premiums, the Federal poverty level, and the individual's most recent income data when redetermining eligibility for subsidies. If the marketplace does not follow the specified processes, the individual cannot be automatically reenrolled in a qualified health plan with subsidies until current income information is provided for redetermination. The marketplace requires current income information for eligibility redetermination for subsidies and credits, following guidance from the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services. The marketplace must ensure comprehensive guidance for annual eligibility redeterminations and reenrollments for coverage and tax credits. Enrollees eligible for automatic reenrollment in a health plan must provide authorization for disclosure of information. The marketplace must provide authorization for disclosure of information to verify eligibility for credits or cost-sharing reductions, request updated income information annually, and give timely notices for redeterminations and reenrollments. The term "marketplace" refers to State Based Exchanges and the Federally Facilitated Exchange under the Affordable Care Act.
